head.title: Neglected Children Gain in Foster Care

hedline.hl1: Neglected Children Gain in Foster Care

abstract.p: Bonnie Le Var letter on Martin Guggenheim's July 8 article holds foster care will only benefit neglected children if it provides safe, caring environment

block.p: Martin Guggenheim (''Sometimes, Foster Care Is the Easy Way Out,'' Op-Ed, July 8) reports that ''only 10 percent of the children who end up in foster care are there because of physical or sexual abuse.'' What about the remaining 90 percent, who are placed in foster care because of parental neglect?

Martin Guggenheim (''Sometimes, Foster Care Is the Easy Way Out,'' Op-Ed, July 8) reports that ''only 10 percent of the children who end up in foster care are there because of physical or sexual abuse.'' What about the remaining 90 percent, who are placed in foster care because of parental neglect?

The National Center of Child Abuse and Neglect reported that neglect has been the predominant type of maltreatment of children. Maltreatment of children nearly doubled from 1986 to 1993, according to the Department of Health and Human Services.

While it is true that sensational cases should not dictate policy, I disagree that foster care is the easy way out. However, foster care will only benefit a neglected child if it provides a safe and caring environment.
BONNIE LE VAR White Plains, July 8, 1998
The writer, a social worker, is a research associate at the Institute for Socioeconomic Studies.
